sn35.74:4.2: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha,
sn35.74:4.4: “Sir, in such and such a monastery there’s a mendicant who is junior and not well known. He’s sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn35.74:4.5: Please go to him out of compassion.”
sn35.74:5.1: When the Buddha heard that the mendicant was junior and ill, understanding that he was not well known, he went to him.
sn35.74:5.2: That mendicant saw the Buddha coming off in the distance
sn35.74:5.3: and tried to rise on his cot.
sn35.74:5.4: Then the Buddha said to that monk:
sn35.74:5.5: “It’s all right, Phagguṇa, don’t get up.
sn35.74:5.6: There are some seats indicated, I will sit there.”
sn35.74:5.7: He sat on the indicated seat
sn35.74:5.9: “I hope you’re keeping well, mendicant; I hope you’re alright. I hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading, not growing, is apparent.”
sn35.74:6.1: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing, not fading, is apparent.”
sn35.74:7.1: “I hope you don’t have any remorse or regrets?”
sn35.74:8.1: “Indeed, sir, I have no little remorse and regrets.”
sn35.74:9.1: “I hope you have no reason to blame yourself when it comes to ethical conduct?”
sn35.74:10.1: “No sir, I have no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct.”
sn35.74:11.1: “In that case, mendicant, why do you have remorse and regrets?”
sn35.74:12.1: “Because I understand that the Buddha has not taught the Dhamma merely for the sake of ethical purity.”
sn35.74:13.1: “If that is so, what exactly do you understand to be the purpose of teaching the Dhamma?”
sn35.74:14.1: “I understand that the Buddha has taught the Dhamma for the purpose of the fading away of greed.”
sn35.74:15.2: It’s good that you understand that I’ve taught the Dhamma for the purpose of the fading away of greed.
sn35.74:15.3: For that is indeed the purpose.
sn35.74:15.4: What do you think, mendicant? Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
sn35.74:19.1: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn35.74:21.1: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and liable to fall apart, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn35.74:21.2: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn35.74:23.1: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple becomes disillusioned with the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
sn35.74:23.5: When freed, they know ‘it is freed’.
sn35.74:23.7: … there is no return to any state of existence.’”
sn35.74:24.1: This is what the Buddha said.
sn35.74:24.2: Uplifted, that mendicant approved of what the Buddha said.
sn35.74:24.3: And while this discourse was being spoken, the spotless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in that mendicant:
sn35.74:24.4: “Everything that has a beginning has an end.”
